content.webTitle: Gus Poyet says Sunderland is ‘a different club’ with Jermain Defoe

fields.headline: Gus Poyet says Sunderland is ‘a different club’ with Jermain Defoe
fields.bodyText: Jermain Defoe is still putting names to faces and learning how to get from the training ground to the stadium but already Gus Poyet believes the former England striker has transformed Sunderland. “There’s no doubt the club is a different club today,” said Poyet, who seems the happiest he has been for months following Defoe’s arrival in a part exchange deal which has taken Jozy Altidore to Toronto. The decision to offer a three-and-a-half-year contract, albeit heavily incentivised, worth somewhere in the region of £70,000 a week to a 32-year-old has been widely queried but Sunderland’s manager is certain the investment will pay dividends. “We think Jermain deserves the length of contract,” said the Uruguayan, who hopes to give Defoe a debut, either from the start or off the bench, at his former club Tottenham Hotspur on Saturday. “We’re convinced it’s the right decision. It was a perfect deal really. Perfect deals don’t happen very often. They’re practically impossible.” Poyet was full of praise for Lee Congerton, the club’s sporting director, for pulling off a complex deal which took around three weeks to construct. Moreover he is adamant Defoe’s presence means that, as manager, he must now shoulder increased responsibility. “I am telling you there are no excuses now,” he said. “I am responsible, so whatever happens from this point onwards is down to me. I cannot say one thing one day and then change when it suits me. I don’t like excuses but I know every now and then something comes out of me and can sound like excuses. Now I hope there are no more. We were missing something in front of goal but now we’ve got Jermain.” After winning only three Premier League games all season Sunderland are perched on the brink of the relegation zone with their manager heavily criticised for some negative tactics. In return for spending heavily on Defoe’s contract the club’s board are evidently hoping to see a more attractive and adventurous team rebuilt round the newcomer. “We need to adapt to Jermain and we’ll try to change,” said Poyet, who believes a striker he both played with and coached at Spurs could be back in the England squad by the summer. “We’re going to develop something different. In the past we found it easier to be organised with one striker up front and the other working hard out wide.. Now it’s a big possibility we’ll start playing with two up front. There are plenty of things we could do differently. It could be a typical English 4-4-2, it could be a diamond or it could be five at the back, like Liverpool had with [Luis] Suárez and [Daniel] Sturridge up front.”Sunderland’s manager did not discount the possibility of Sturridge and Defoe appearing in future England teams together. “If Jermain plays and he’s fit and he scores goals, I’m sure the manager of the national team is going to try to get him,” he said. “First, he wants to get back into the Barclays Premier League, prove that he can keep scoring goals, help us and then it’s up to Mr Roy Hodgson. But that’s the second step. The first one is to get back into business.” Defoe cannot wait to get started. “I’m delighted to be here,” he said. “Sunderland’s a great club and I’ve always enjoyed coming up here because of the stadium and the fans. It’s a great place to play football. “It was good over in Toronto, I enjoyed it. But for me, the Premier League is the best league in the world and when you step away from it, you realise how good it is. To be honest, I just missed it. I wanted to come back and be back in the Premier League scoring goals.” He is not entirely surprised to be making his debt at White Hart Lane. “That’s always how it happens isn’t it?” he said. “It’s crazy. It’s going to be tough. I’d been at Tottenham for 10 years, it’s a good club – but if we create chances and, hopefully take them I believe we can win the game.”
